summary:
**London Today:**

**Consumer Affairs & Cost of Living:**
A secret investigation into locksmith services in London has revealed instances of extreme overcharging, with a couple reportedly paying over £5,000 instead of the quoted £50. Meanwhile, six million low-income households will continue receiving £150 off their energy bills as the government extends the support for the next five years. 

**Diplomatic Relations & Public Policy:**
Diplomats owe a staggering £165 million in unpaid congestion charges in London, highlighting ongoing tensions around diplomatic privileges and responsibilities.

**Urban Development & Culture:**
Wandsworth Council has approved a major height expansion for Vivienne Westwood's headquarters, a move set to aid the fashion brand’s international growth. On a cultural note, London celebrates 40 years of poetry on the Underground, inviting citizens to contribute their own verses.

**Health & Science:**
Concerns arise over a potential link between weight-loss injections and a 15% surge in gallbladder removal surgeries last year, prompting calls from surgeons for more research into the matter.

**Crime & Justice:**
In distressing crime updates, a lorry driver was sentenced for preparing a 'race war', a Great Ormond Street doctor was found to have harmed nearly 100 children through botched surgeries, ex-nursery worker Vincent Chan admits to numerous child sex offences, and a school mentor jailed for past abuses. Additionally, the police have made a fifth arrest related to arson attacks on properties linked to the Prime Minister.

**Sports & Entertainment:**
In sports, Crystal Palace's pursuit of striker Jorgen Strand Larsen is uncertain, Emma Raducanu splits from her coach after the Australian Open, and Sutton United address racist abuse against new player Jermaine Francis. Transfer activities see Charlton and Bromley securing players on loan deals for the remainder of the season. Queens Park Rangers focus on mental resilience in upcoming matches.
